comments.author: TheBurek

comments.text:
+TheBurek
Terrorism generally means an act of violence meant to achieve some 
political (or perhaps religious) goal by spreading fear even among people 
not otherwise directly affected by the act. More recently it has also 
gained a moral component (i.e. we only call an act terrorist if we disagree 
with the act), but in the strict technical sense of the word that´s not 
necessary. In this case Franz Ferdinand was assassinated not (just?) 
because the assassins didn't like him personally, but because they hoped to 
scare Austro-Hungaria into a certain course of action. I think calling it 
terrorism is justified, especially if you use the morally neutral 
definition of the word.

comments.text:
Who are "we"?
I could by that statement assume you were American, but that would be on a 
somewhat derogatory base. This is the internet, we = everybody = also 
people in China and 200 other countries. I do not remember China being in 
the war for one and a lot of other countries (including my own) were 
neutral.

If I am not wrong in thinking you are referring to the US, then it was 
because they had let France and the UK buy a tone of industrial war goods 
on loan, and if they lost the war, then the US would get no payment on 
these loans. And on top of that some stupid propaganda about (1) Lusitania 
(although it did not start until month after the sinking, because now it 
had become good propaganda and not bad propaganda) and (2) after the 
Russian February revolution (not the Red one in October of their calendar, 
the white one) some started arguing that it was a war between liberty and 
tyranny.

But basically it was about money. And when the war ended the USA went from 
the most underrated power in the world, to be viewed the most 
important both in term of money and power.

War is always only about money and power. The American Revolutionary War of 
Independence only succeeded because they had help from France and Spain in 
blockading the British. The only interests of France and Spain was a new 
trading partner and to kick some British butt.

And the whole revolution thing became a bit of a problem for the French 
king not many years later. I even ended in him having major and permanent 
neck surgery. So freedom and democracy is now a goal in war, but it is 
often a bi-product of postwar stabilisation.

And on topic: In WWI there were no good or bad guys, just many power, 
states and nations with many different goals and aspirations. The 
assassination was the trigger, but the point of no return was in 1912, when 
Germany decided that it needed a war with Russia soon or Russia would 
become to strong for Germany to ever have a chance against (Russia had just 
started industrialization at this time and was catching up to Germany, 
while Russia had a lot more people, land and resources than anyone else in 
Europe) . Germany wanted a war and that is why Austria got a blank check, 
and if they had not then in the 1920's or 1930's Russia would have become a 
continental hegemon. And a second Crimean War would not have done a lot of 
good if attempted. Germany saved Europe from Russia in two world wars, but 
went about doing it in such terrible ways that very few feel comfortable 
acknowledging it today.

And in the Balkans everything was chaos, as it has always been and always 
will be. Learn to love the beauty in the chaos, pick your favourites (if 
they were not picked by your passport), and enjoy.
Serbia for one is an awesome place.

Halorecon95 no offence but what you just said is ignorant.
Greater Serbia and Yugoslavia are two entirely DIFFERENT concepts and 
movements. They contrast each other like black and white.

The first pan-Slavists (and inventors of Yugoslavia) were the 16th-century 
Croatian writer Vinko Pribojević and the 17th-century Croatian Catholic 
missionary Juraj Križanić. The catholic priest was the one who actually 
took the ideology from radical writings and kick-started the Yugoslav 
movement.

Croatians invented Yugoslavia and Croatians suggested the idea to the 
French at the end of the Great War that they should unify with the Serbs. 
This is partly why France supported the creation of a Yugoslav state so 
strongly. Croatians wanted to unify with the Serbs! They had a referendum!

Also FYI Serbia had the most multi-ethnic and multi-religious governments 
in the early 20th century in Europe and still is relatively diverse today.
The fact that there were a few corrupt politicians does not mean the system 
didn't function and that Serbs and Croatians on a social level couldn't 
cooperate. Serbs in Krajina in Croatia have been mixing with Croatians for 
over a millennium!

The fact that you made the comment that you did makes me cast doubt on how 
much research and fact there is behind what you said.

Finally it is NOT the west's perspective that Princip was a radical 
militant nationalist who felt sorry for himself and wanted fame. Thats YOUR 
opinion. Making bold statements like that makes me wonder if you have a 
bias?

Anyway i hope i managed to educate you a bit on what history books say and 
not your drunk racist uncle at the dinner table. I hope when you grow out 
of being a teenager you will be more culturally aware. Good luck to you i 
hope i managed to enlighten you on something.

comments.text:
If you want to play the counter factual argument, then the best is:
If the North did not intercept Lees orders before Gettysburg, then the 
South might have won the battle.
This should have been enough for France and the UK to recognize and (more 
likely indirectly than directly) support the South.
South would have seceded. This would have made the US (remaining North) 
overwhelmingly German.
So in WWI the USA would be pro-Germany, while the CSA would be pro-Entende. 
This would have meant that the USA would not have had an influence on 
anything in Europe as the two would cancel each other out. Now a lot of 
industry supporting France and the UK was made in the US (the industry was 
and is in the Northern - pro-German if CSA seceded - states), so not only 
would troops be missing in 1918 to turn the Western front, but also 
supplies.
So it is more likely that the 1918 German summer offensive would actually 
have taken Paris and ended the war on German terms. USSR would not have 
been able to grow as Germany would had maintained its new territories in 
the East as agreed with Lenin.
So no Hitler and Germany would control everything that is today the EU. So 
some would say things would not be a lot different in Europe (well Japan, 
China and the rest of Asia is uncertain), but maybe Germany would have 
maintained Global domination. They main thing would have been that 
individual freedom might be a lot further back, and this coupled with the 
technological possibilities of surveillance might mean that we would like 
in an actual 1984 style society and speaking German.

This is the best butterfly wings flapping style story I know... But 
remember, when you change one thing in history, then perceptions of all 
actors also change and the variables are so great that it is pointless to 
make assumptions about what would happen. But I just like this example as a 
funny story. Nothing is automatic.

If France had lost WWI, then military people such as Petain or Foch or 
someone else might have risen to power in the same would Hindenburg did in 
Germany (which oped for Hitler to come in). De Gaule might have become a 
second Napoleon...

comments.text:
Ones you start an arms race, you end up with a war, when one side can see 
themselves falling behind. The only reasons why this did not happen in The 
Cold War was:
1. The USSR did not realise they had fallen behind, before it was too late.
2. You know... Nukes... Mutual Assured Destruction...

Germany wanted war, therefore it is easy to blame them. But France and 
Serbia also wanted war for other reasons (Alsace-Lorraine - getting 
territory with Serbians from Austria). And there were many other scores to 
settle.

You might as well blame Bismarck. If he had not united Germany, Austria 
would not have become the dual-monarchy and in that showed weakness that 
could give rise to Serbia daring to challenge them. The same goes for 
taking Alsace-Lorraine from France. And also for making Germany so powerful 
that it challenged the status quo of European power.

Hitler coming to power was not a result of German actions, it was a result 
of external actions. First the Versailles treaty pissed of the Germans, and 
then the Wall Street crash that ruined the international economy and sent 
Germany back into depression, which meant the Germans had their final straw 
of democracy (there was also the far left, that was anti-democratic, which 
had about 1/4 to 1/3 of the vote towards the end of the Weimar Republic).

The First World War was for us today a good war. It fixed European borders 
and showed that one country cannot just rule the others. And the Second 
World War (ending in 1989) then took all the ideological challenges that 
had been thought up by various people. Both were necessary to get to where 
we are today. The Second World War was probably not necessary, but the 
First one was. Just like the 30 Years War made us (Western Europe) stop 
being complete idiots about who had what religion.

Past wars were terrible, but a lot of good also comes from having them and 
then understanding them afterwards (something they still have not learnt in 
the Balkans for some reason and a lot of other places) and seizing the 
moment. Because the history of the Western Civilisation is written in peace 
treaties and seen in the institutions they create.

comments.text:
+AccentedGamer Haha thanks. Well I can give you an example of how nations 
thought of others as lesser sure:

Russia was seen by Germany and most of the other European Powers as 
barbaric, backwards, and not up to par with the rest of the nations. This 
was only slightly true. Russia was certainly less industrialized than say 
Germany but they were catching up fast (Finished the Trans-Siberian 
Railroad in 1916 for example). Germany wanted to become the powerhouse of 
Europe and the high German command saw a war with Russia in the near 
future. 

Austria-Hungary was a mixed bag. It was a very diverse state. Ethnic 
Austrians saw themselves as being the greatest especially when compared to 
their Slavic Balkan counterparts (Like the Serbians). Austria-Hungary 
thought that they would crush Serbia in the war and that there was no way 
Serbia could hold out against their great army. In actuality Serbia fought 
off against numerous attacks and it wasn't until Bulgaria, and Germany 
helped out with yet another Serbia/Montenegro invasion that Serbia was 
wiped out. 

France and the United Kingdom had a longstanding rivalry. They, with 
Russia, were allies in the Triple Entente but this doesn't mean they really 
liked eachother. Actually researchers has found documents stating that the 
two had plans for invading one other before World War 1 began. England (UK, 
I'm just gonna refer to it as England cause it's easier) was only allied 
with France, whom they didn't really like, and Russia their "All time 
Rival) because the German Navy was the only one strong enough to attack 
England.

Germany was scene as savages in the Entente powers during war time. A lot 
of anti-German propaganda pictured the Germans as barbaric apes with simple 
minds. In actuality the Germans was a major cultural and economic 
powerhouse before World War 1. Something many of the other European powers 
strongly admired.

Nationalism is a mixed idea. It can give people pride in ones country but 
it also makes countries see themselves as the ultimate country. No other 
country is worthy of being compared and that was no more evident than in 
the years following World War 1.

As for specifically Franz Ferdinand's sense of Nationalistic pride I would 
suggest reading a Biography on him as I don't know too much on his personal 
beliefs as a whole.

What I do know about Franz Ferdinand was that he was one of the few 
Austrian High Command that didn't want a war with Russia and was willing to 
prevent one at all costs. He knew that the Slavic pride between Russia and 
Serbia was strong. He still saw the Slavic people as backwards (Many people 
did) but he knew that Austria would most likely be crushed in a war against 
Russia.

comments.text:
+Rogy N Please in the future right in paragraph, it makes it a lot easier 
to read, as it is clearer when you are switching subtopic...

The bombings were against the Serbian military. Therefore you not only bomb 
it in Kosovo, but all over Serbia. If there is a bridge 200 km north of 
Kosovo that is part of a supply line, then you bomb that. If there is a TV 
station that is offering strategic communication in cooperation with the 
military, then that is a lawful military target. This is all very much a 
question of how much the directly or indirectly supported the war effort, 
and a very many civilian things support a war effort in ways that you do 
not directly think about. I could make up 10 different reasons, for why it 
would be okay to bomb a TV station, but I do not know the reasoning at the 
time, so I am not going to speculate.

Now what you hit is not important. It is what you try to hit. And war 
crimes is nothing new to the West (Dresden is a good example). But still 
there is no evidence of "intent" (this is what matters legally), so until 
you can prove intent, then nothing wrong was done. You can have theories, 
but until you can prove anything, then your theories have no values.

The 4 big baddies are not countries, people or something like that, they 
are the worst breaches to international law that all states are obligated 
to do something about. Which is also why Serbia (although it should have 
been Yugoslavia) was guilty of failing to prevent genocide, as all states 
have an obligation to take action to prevent genocide. Which actually means 
that when Milosevic knew that the situation was out of control in 
Srebrenica (which there is evidence supporting that he knew, exactly what 
was going on, but was not in command or control of it) it was his legal 
obligation to do anything to prevent genocide, which in this case would 
have been to notify NATO commanders of what was going on (which effectively 
would have meant treason in the eyes of Serbians).

I did not watch the specific cases, as I do not have a personal interest in 
the specifics... And I have some issues with some aspects of international 
criminal law. Also why I did not take an electorate course we have in my 
masters called "Prosecution of War Crimes", and I kept making the joke of 
calling the course "Persecution" instead of "Prosecution"... But that is 
not going to make me care about the specific cases. It might be that not

profile. Serbia bet on Russia, and there was and still is a grand strategy 
of reducing Russia's Western influence to zero. Serbia picked a really 
stupid time to challenge Western hegemony. If the Kosovo War had been after 
Milosevic and 9/11, then you could have shut those Albanians up for 
good....... Solving the East-West divide is mostly about Russia accepting 
the reality of things. They need to make friendly arrangements with 
neighbours instead of relying on threats to protect Russia minorities and 
enter into the European community. And to me that actually means Russia 
joining the EU and NATO, but lets just wait a few decades before that is 
going to happen.

Also remember that double standards are a natural part of any political and 
military campaign. The truth is in people's nature, and not in what they 
say... And in a time of war a lot of things are very different from 
everyday life. Liberal (Western) values are about ideals, and trying to 
reach as much freedom for the individual as possible, but when you go to

Yes, I am a huge Lazio fan... I might not have been able to see the Serbia 
perspective in this, if it was not for the actions of Stankovic and 
especially Mihajlovic back then...

comments.text:
+Rogy N Well, I think we mostly disagree on what a high level collateral 
damage is... And knowing well that you are bombing civilians is perfectly 
acceptable, if you also hit something of military value (it is a bit more 
complex than that, but that is essentially how the rules are).

Your point about "USA players" at the end makes no sense in the context...

International law is not a joke. A lot of countries put a lot of focus on 
it. After the ICJ case Serbia apologised for failing to stop the genocide 
in Srebrenica (although Serbia is not legally the continuation of 
Yugoslavia). But there is the fundamental problem in issues of 
"International Peace and Security" (the specific and very important wording 
in the UN Charter), where essentially the UN is obligated to react, but 
sometimes certain countries (Russia and China) veto such actions, therefore 
there is a legal question if there exists a "Responsibility to Protect" 
(which was the idea behind the Kosovo intervention) or not, and that is 
still not decided (for or against). Russia has though used an R2P argument 
in Georgia in 2008, so even the sceptical countries are not completely 
against it.

International law is just like any other law up to interpretation. Russia 
sees some things one way, America sees them in another, and far from all 
countries have ratified the same treaties, so very few things are illegal 
for everyone. Except the 4 big baddies: aggression (war for territorial 
gains), war crimes (Geneva conventions), crimes against humanity, and 
genocide.

Serbia decided on their own to drop having a case before the ICJ on NATO 
carrying out an intervention without a UN mandate (aid apparently was more 
interesting). That is why no Western country has been held responsible, and 
post intervention a UN resolution legitimized the intervention.

Now before ICTY the cases have been taking forever. As I understand it is 
because the evidence in such cases is very problematic, as proving who did, 
knew of, and ordered what is difficult to prove. One of my professors was 
the Danish judge at ICTY (though it was not a course on ICTY), and well he 
did not change my mind about a potential discourse against Serbia. But I 
have seen no evidence that anyone not guilty was put in jail, and not had a 
fair chance to defend themselves and cases can take very long, when you 
(like Šešelj) also have contempt of court cases that need to be handled... 
If someone is actually guilty, but there is not enough evidence, then they 
still do not go to jail. But well there is a huge difference between 
international criminal law and public international law... International 
criminal law is still in its infancy and therefore not functioning as well 
as it should. But before an international court or tribunal it is not 
strange that cases take many years to complete.

As things are now, nothing on this can change, and the most important part 
of that is Serbia not pushing it. I completely understand and respect your 
position, but it feels like you unfortunately are a bit stuck in the 
historical Serbian narrative.
A lot of things have changed in the last 100 years after national 
self-determination became important after the end of WWI (but not really 
got into effect until after the collapse of the Soviet Union and 
Yugoslavia), and today Serbia is choosing its own path, no one is forcing 
them into anything, but if you challenge the powers, then there will always 
be consequences. Looking forward and building a better future for Serbia is 
more important than the past. Especially if we want to limit the influence 
of political islam in Europe...

comments.text:
+Rogy N At that time smart bombs were not so smart as today (in 1999 some 
of them even ended up in Bulgaria). And not all bombs are smart bombs as 
that is financially impossible. So most munitions used are classic dumb 
bombs which can fly far off their target. And where there no military 
targets in Niš? Remember bridges, power plants and other elements of 
infrastructure that in any way can support a military force is a military 
target. It is not just about actual military personel, vehicles and units. 
Because as you rightly pointed out, they are a lot easier to hide than 
something fixed (buildings, bridges etc.).

Mistakes happen a lot in war and many civilians die... 500 confirmed and at 
most 5000 suspected civilian casualties in a 2-3 week bombing campaign is 
extremely low. Calling 15 deaths in one case a lot is completely 
disproportional with the realities of war... If it was not for skilled 
airmanship and accuracy of the weapons used, you should have expected a 
civilian death toll in the tens of thousands...

Bombing cities with cluster bombs was not illegal. There is a long ethical 
debate on it, but by the standards that Kosovo, Serbia and the rest of the 
World have accepted that is not even close to the scope of the atrocities 
carried out by both sides inside of Kosovo.

That the operation never should have happened is the relevant point, but I 
would like you to carry out such an air campaign with fewer civilian deaths 
with the technology of the day. Unless you can prove beyond reasonable 
doubt in a court of law that the individual bombs was intentionally dropped 
to hit a non-military target with the purpose of killing civilians, then 
you have no argument for anything but logical collateral damage in time of 
war (both the pilot and the officers designing the mission knew they where 
murdering civilians).

And if you want to know, why Serbia was bombed, then it was because 
Milosevic decided not to follow the International Community, but do his own 
thing (since Srebrenica the whole of the West was just looking for an 
excuse, and we got it in Kosovo). And yes, at that time what the US and 
Europe said was the International Community was the International 
Community, as the end of the Cold War had made the US the worlds single 
superpower and even stronger than that with allies (which is not the case 
any more, the US is not that powerful on its own any more).

If Milosevic and his system had been forced out earlier, then you would 
have started of with a clean slate. Kosovo should never have been taken 
from you, but really it is your own fault that you lost it. Milosevic tried 
to play big politics and he lost.

And you can make a million arguments about the other sides, it is a 
disgrace that so few have been taken to The Hague over the crimes against 
Serbians... There are many criminals that still need to be brought to 
justice over the Yugoslavian and Kosovo Civil Wars... But a big issue is 
the lack of evidence and the perceived bias against Serbia. You lost the 
media war, which is often more important than the actual war, and in both 
cases the Bosniaks and Albanians managed to win it, losing a war is one 
thing losing the perception of who was right and wrong is a lot bigger of a 
problem. If you want Serbia to be treated justly, then you have to 
objectively prove that the others were just as bad, and that is before and 
international court... Because all the evidence points to Serbia being a 
lot worse than all the other sides of the conflict (and therefore 
unreasonable measures was taken to punish Serbia as a result).

comments.text:
+Frank White I do not argue the history is written by the winners thing. 
The problem about understanding even WWII is we do not have access to the 
Russian archives. When Barbarossa started the Russians where in what seemed 
logically offensive positions and there is some talk about Germany maybe 
have saved Europe for an coming Russian invasion... But 14 days that saved 
the world is not exactly written by pillars in the historic community. But 
if it is true (which would not be off compared to how Stalin was going 
about things), then you might want to start thinking about Nazi Germany as 
not just the bad guys.

From my perspective good and evil are term for narrow minded people who are 
unable to understand the nuances of human beings.

Britain and France did not go to war for their love of Poland, there was 
nothing noble about it. They did so because they knew they would have to. 
They created the monster through the Versailles treaty (although not really 
relevant by 1933, the damage had been done in the eyes of the German 
population). They were fixing their own mess that they should never have 
made to begin with.

America entered the war because they entered into an oil embargo on Japan 
that forced Japan to war (which the US well knew). They just needed a 
little Pearl Harbour to get the population on for the whole war thing.

There will always be someone who suffered at the people you see as the 
good. Intentionally creating a firestom (something that in of it self 
served no military purpose) over Dresden was a war crime, but for some 
reason neither the British or the Americans had the balls to put Le May and 
Harry in front of a firing squad.

"War does not determine who is right - only who is left."
Bertrand Russell

On the Balkans: Does that book take into account the bosniaks massacred by 
croats? Or later on Serbian in Kosovo being harvested for organs? There is 
enough blame to go around, and the problem is not the different 
perspectives it is the lack of responsibility being taken on all sides. And 
this is not just about Yugoslavia, it is the same all over the Balkans. 
Peace comes when people give up their pride, and that is probably never 
happen in the Balkans, because many have very little more than their pride.

My core point is that you only have the sources you have access to. You 
have a lot more than from 500 years ago, but you still do not have the most 
important ones as they are locked up in archives as long as they have a 
relevance in the politics of today. And even if two people have access to 
the same sources they will prioritize them different and have different 
baggage. We are humans, we attribute value to things and mostly other 
humans. To understand history we structure our knowledge, which means when 
we make our first prioritizations, then we often forge a part that we only 
deviate slightly from when gaining new sources, as we know that no sources 
are objective.

Another source aspect is that primary sources rarely get translated, so you 
are reading a lot of secondary sources that have original sources in a 
language you cannot read, and therefore a lot (if not most of you 
information for most people) has already gone through at least one 
interpretation before you get to look at it.

So really, we do not know that much as individuals. History is not about 
truth, and it has never been about truth. Humans are terrible at 
understanding truth. Even in science where they get close to objective 
truth, often the human element ruins it. History is about the human element 
and those humans' (or states') perceptions of the reality they were in. In 
understanding ourself past self we understand our present.

I strongly disagree with the whole notion of facts and truth. If facts were 
to prevalent in history, how come for 50 years no one said anything about 
how 4 million jew where supposedly killed in Auschwitz, while 6 million 
where killed in total, and most where killed by einsatzgruppen. History is 
about emotions and perceptions. No one wants a good story (or as per my 
example: a sad story) ruined by normative "facts", which in reality are 
subjective interpretations that a lot of people happen to agree on for a 
wide variety of reasons.

I remember in a method class (studying history) my professor saying:
Question everything... [*pause*] eh except the Holocaust.

Ones you have exceptions to anything between you and objectivity (which 
includes your own brains interpretation of information), the you are not 
dealing in facts. And it is a massive problem for the understanding of 
history, when people forget that facts are irrelevant, and that the subject 
is not about understanding the past, it is about understanding yourself and 
how you see the world. The is why history is in the humanities department 
and it still confuses social scientists (my minor and now my masters).

More meta and methodology would be nice in Crash Course History, but it 
would probably scare of the intended audience...

comments.text:
In France and in the UK (also Germany, but overshadowed by later events), 
there is a sense among the intelligentsia that WW1 was a reversal of the 
19th century's general trend towards progress and liberalism. When it 
happened and in the particular way that it happened, it was a very rude 
awakening. WW2 was not the same kind of shock, since the concept of a 
hugely destructive world war was not new. The casualty figures quoted 
earlier are broadly accurate - more Brits and French died in WW1 as in WW2. 
But also, the deaths in WW1 fell much more specifically on young combatant 
men, including many of the elite who went on to write history and 
literature. So in some sense it was more personally impactful on the 
"opinion makers" of the time.

that's because the Netherlands wasn't involved in WWI. Just go to Belgium 
for Remembrance Day (can't remember what the Belgians call it), aka 
November 11, and see how big of a deal it was. A significant portion of WWI 
battles happened in Flanders (aka the Northern, Flemish speaking part of 
Belgium), which was basically reduced to rubble. Cities like Ieper (aka 
Ypres) were rebuilt after the war to look medieval, but photos from 1918 
show a big pile of rocks and not much else. They (Ieper) also have a huge 
WW1 museum. WWI was slow and effected the places it was fought VERY 
strongly, whereas WW2 was fast (blitzkrieg) and affected more places but 
did less damage to the cities themselves. I guess the biggest difference is 
WW1 damaged cities and infrastructure terribly while WW2 damaged people. 
(as a GROSS oversimplification)

comments.text:
+adamarimba


Well just off the top of my head from what i can remember him saying some 
time ago 

1. Princip was NOT part of The Black Hand, he was part of the Young-Bosnia 
movement. These are two distinctly separate organisations with different 
goals and different compositions. I don't know how well informed you are on 
the situation but this is not opinion this is a fact. Comparing The Black 
Hand to the Young-Bosnia movement is like comparing apples to oranges. The 
only Similarity the two groups have is literally the fact that they both 
have Serbs, though one is exclusively Serb and the other isn't. 
If you would like me to you can request me to write you up a detailed 
explanation of their differences and what they are about.
One thing i would like to mention now is that the assassins were 
pro-yugoslav, regardless of its form. They had nothing to do with the 
concept of Greater Serbia, which concept didn't even exist back then. I'll 
go further into this later in my post.

2. He implies The Black Hand and the Serbian government were practically 
the same thing and went together like peanut butter and jelly. This is 
false. The two had almost nothing to do with each other. Yes some 
individuals far and few between from the government might've been members 
of the Black Hand and many sympathetic but calling them two peas in a pod 
is a gross exaggeration. The Black Hand and the Serbian government's 
relationship is comparable to the Masons in The U.S.A. and the United 
States Government, maybe less so. Conspiracy Theories aside the two in both 
instances have nothing to do with each other really.

3. The Serbs accepted the entire ultimatum but the Austrians attacked anyway

4. He called Gavrilo Princip a terrorist. I cannot begin to to emphasis how 
biased, narrow sighted, myopic, and derogatory that is and even somewhat 
racist that statement is. You only need to read the comments section to 
understand but if you want i can give you a super-compact-nutshell 
understanding of the situation.

Contrast to what Mr.Green said there was a build up to the war and there 
definitely was uncertainty amongst the governments. Following the 2nd 
Balkan war in which Serbia led the liberation of Eastern Europe from the 
Ottoman empire there was something called the Berlin conference in which 
every single European country attended (except Bulgaria) and discussed 
issues facing the newly freed Balkan states, including who had claim to 
Bosnia.

Due to the the history of the Balkan Wars (which you can read up on if you 
want) almost the entirety of Europe conferred Bosnia to their culturally 
similar counterpart Serbia. Despite this agreement Austria-Hungary annexed 
Bosnia anyway and basically told the rest of Europe 'what are you going to 
do about it'. The Austrians ruled Bosnia with a bloody iron fist. As a 
result of this occupation (and it was nothing less than that) a number of 
liberation movements sprung up of seeped into Bosnia, one of whom being the 
Young-Bosnia movement.

Let me now explain why Gavrilo Princip is not a terrorist but a freedom 
fighter. Would shooting a Nazi Waffen SS Officer in the Balkans during the 
1940s be wrong and an act of terrorism? No? How then is this situation any 
different? Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria was an occupier, who came to 
a Serbian dominated city on major national holiday, emotions flaring, so 
that the duke can flex his political muscles, moderate or not and deserved 
to be assassinated.
By the way interesting fact; the original assassin of the plot was supposed

One of the reason we do focus so heavily on the 20th Century (besides the 
fact that it still resonates today) is the sheer bulk and ready 
availability of so much information pertaining to this time period. If one 
looks back at the 11th Century (in Europe, let's say) you would be 
immediately hindered by the limited primary sources available, particularly 
if you are studying social, cultural, or artistic history. Too often in the 
past documents reflected politics, religion, and the military (in the 
European context, that is), leaving other areas of historical development 
undocumented and, thus, lesser known to us. With the 20th Century we have 
film, audio recordings, billions of primary documents, and people still 
alive who experienced/made that history.

captions.text:
Hi, I'm John Green, this is Crash Course World
History and today we're going to talk about

World War I. We actually have two videos about
World War I. Today we're going to talk about

how World War I happened. Next week we're
going to talk about why. World War I is a

really big deal. Especially to those of us
who are really interested in like, industrialization

and nation-states and modernity. So usually
we don't talk that much about wars, but we're
going to make an exception.

Mr. Green, Mr. Green, "Exception?" Cue the
Mongol-tage.

Yeah, no me from the past. We don't roll the
Mongol-tage every time we use the word exception,

we roll it when we're talking about how the
Mongols are an exception to a lot of our assumptions
about civilizations.

Stan, Stan- No, there are no Mongols today, we
are talking about World War I.

So I'm filming this in 2014, which means that
the great war started 100 years ago and the

World War I Centenary is just so hot right
now, I can't miss out on it.

So most historians agree that the event that
started World War I was the assassination

of Austrian archduke Franz Ferdinand on June 28,
1914, but beyond that, there's not a lot of agreement.

Others say the war really started after Franz
Ferdinand bit it. Like when Germany declared

war or when Russia mobilized. So looking at
why a war or any historical event happened

means looking for a cause and effect relationship
that implicitly assumes that if one particular

event in a chain of events had gone differently,
the historical outcome would also be different.

This is why we have alternate history novels.
Right , like what would have happened in the

American Civil War if the South had won the
Battle at Gettysburg? What would have happened

if the Nazis had repulsed the D-day invasion?
In both cases, probably eventually the same
outcome but that's neither here nor there.

The question we're looking at today is how.
And that's a much more modest question because

we can simply discuss a series of events but
it's still a complicated one

because when you're talking about how, you're
always picking from an uncountable number

of things that happened. You know, a butterfly
flaps its wings and that leads to a series

of events and then eventually across the world
an archduke gets killed.

So even when it comes to a relatively straightforward
question like how, you'll never get to the

bottom of all of it, but today we're going
to discuss some of the how.

So one way or another, all wars start with
a breakdown in peaceful relations between

the eventual belligerents and World War I
is no exception.

Oh, for the love of agriculture please stop
it.

Right, but World War I is a bit unusual in
that we have a concrete event and a date to

start our discussion. Sometimes we get lucky,
historically, and there's an invasion that

starts a war like in the Korean conflict or the firing
on Fort Sumter in the American Civil War.

But other times, it's much more butterfly
effect-y with events that might or might not

lead to a war, building upon each other until
one side mobilizes or declares war or there's
a fight over who shot first.

But here we have a specific assassination of a
specific archduke, Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo.

Now it wasn't a great day for Franz to visit
Bosnia since it was the anniversary of the

Serbs defeat at Kosovo Polje in 1389 and also
St. Vitus's day, which was a celebration for

Slavic nationalists and a Bosnian Serb named
Gavrilo Princip and his co-conspirators chose

to celebrate Slavic nationalism by killing
Franz Ferdinand.

Now they didn't choose Franz Ferdinand at random. He
was the heir apparent of the Austro-Hungarian Empire

Franz Ferdinand wasn't particularly well liked,
not by his uncle who was the head of the Austro-Hungarian Empire,

certainly not by Bosnian Serb nationalists,
also not really by everyone else in Europe

except for the German Kaiser, but Franz Ferdinand
was in his way kind of a moderate.

Oh it's time for the open letter. Oh look
it's a collection of my favorite assassinated
moderates. It's hard out there for a moderate.
An open letter to moderates:

Dear moderates, so one of the reasons that
Franz Ferdinand's uncle didn't like him that

much is that the emperor was really hardcore,
whereas Franz Ferdinand, you know, he was
kind of a moderate.

He was like you know, "I'm an Austro-Hungarian
through and through but I see the Serbian arguement."

Really, Franz Ferdinand was the one leader
in the empire who might have come up with

a solution to the problems of Serbian expansion
and Bosnian independence. And murdering moderates

has a way of making other moderates, you know,
more extreme. In short moderates, your work

may not be romantic, it may not appeal to
the youth, but it is heroic and very dangerous.
Best wishes, John Green.

So even though Franz Ferdinand's uncle didn't
particularly like him, as the emperor of Austria-Hungary,

he felt a certain responsibility to, you know,
do something. Otherwise the Serbia nationalists

would feel like they could expand their territory
at the expense of the empire, so despite what

you often hear about World War I being pointless,
this makes sense as a point sort of.

Now it's a bit of schoolyard bully kind of
diplomacy, but it does make a certain sense,

if Serbia can get bigger, then all of the
other places will think that they can have

have nations too. Soon enough, you don't have
an empire.

Now there's still some debate about whether
Princip and his fellow assassins acted alone

or as part of a larger conspiracy organized
by the Serbian government. But the Austrians

certainly thought there was broader involvement which
is why the whole thing ended up becoming a war.

So Princip was a member of the scary sounding
Black Hand, a group dedicated to creating

a greater Serbia that would include Bosnia
and there's some evidence that the Serbian

chief of military intelligence was in on the
assassination plot or at least knew about it.

In fact, it's likely that the bombs and
pistols the assassins used were supplied by

a Serbian army officer, but this is still
pretty controversial so much so that people
are currently fighting about it in comments.

So almost a month after the assassination,
on July 23, Austria issued an ultimatum to

Serbia. And Austria intentionally made the
demands so harsh that the Serbs would inevitably

have to reject them and ergo war, but that
doesn't explain the month long delay.

What happened in that month? Well Austria's
foreign minister, Berchtold, was afraid that

if they attacked Serbia, Russia would then
attack Austria-Hungary, so the Austrians spent

that month talking to their ally, Germany
to make sure the Germans would have Austria's

back. The Austro-Hungarians got assurance
on July 5 or July 6 in the form of what has

been called the "blank check", a promise from Germany
that they would help Austria if Russia mobilized.

And it was clear that the Germans expected
the Austrians to move quickly in

response to the assassination, not like wait
for another twenty days. So usually I don't

care about dates, but at this point the timing becomes
pretty important. Let's go to the Thought Bubble.

So when the Serbs received the Austrians ultimatum,
Russia declared itself to be in a period preparatory

to war, which sounds a lot like mobilization
but technically it wasn't, which Russia's
foreign minister emphasized to the Germans.

The Tsar proved the measure on July 25, and
it went into effect on July 26.

The Serbs rejected Austria's ultimatum on
July 25, but they made their rejection sound

like a capitulation so the Germans thought
that war had been averted. And they were kind

of surprised then on July 28 when Austria
suddenly declared war on Serbia even though

the Austrian army wasn't actually ready to
start fighting.

Then on July 30, Russia exited its period
preparatory to war and actually officially

mobilized. Germany warned the Russians to
stand down but two days later on August 1,

France mobilized it's armed forces in support
of Russia and that same day, Germany mobilized
and declared war on Russia.

So if you're keeping score at home - and good
historians always do - Austria and Germany

were the first to declare war on July 28 and
August 1 respectively, but Russia with its

pre-mobilization mobilization was actually
ready to begin fighting before Serbia rejected
Austria's ultimatum.

Anyway, then Germany declared war on France
on August 3, marched through Belgium to invade,

hoping to quickly knock out the French and
focus on Russia. Sorry France but you know
Russia's a big deal and you, you know.

German troops crossed Belgium's border on
August 4 and the British issued an ultimatum

to the Germans telling them to get out of
Belgium or else. Germany chose "or else" and

Britain declared war. So by August 4, 1914,
all the major powers involved in World War
I were officially at war with each other.
Thanks Thought Bubble.

Now I know there were a lot of other powers
that would get involved later including the

United States, and Japan, and the Ottoman
Empire -- even Italy.

But for the nations who did most of the actual
fighting, Germany, Austria-Hungary, Russia,

Serbia, France, Great Britain, the war happened
both very quickly and very slowly.

Now looking back, it all happened almost at
once but if you're in the middle of it, a

month is a long time and at any point someone,
like say the archduke, Franz Ferdinand could
have come in and said, "Wait a second."
Well I guess not anyone because he was dead.

But that's how an act of terrorism in a Bosnian
city turned into the first major European

war of the 20th century. A war that still
resonates today. Now the Austrians and the

Serbs probably both imagined that the war
could stay localized to the Balkans especially

since there had been previous conflicts in the
region that hadn't blown up into a world war.

You know, like in 1908 and 1912 and 1913.
We'll get into what made 1914 different next week.

The "why's" of course will always be very
complicated, but for now please remember that

we are always in the middle of a "how." Those
living in June and July of 1914 could never

have imagined how significant that month would
be for human history and when thinking about

them, it's worth remembering that we also
can't imagine what our decisions today will
mean in 100 years.
Thanks for watching. I'll see you next week.
